metadata.title: Canada's annual inflation rate eases to 1.7% in July, core measures stay firm

left: Canada's annual inflation rate decreased to 1.7% in July, down from 1.9% in June, according to Statistics Canada.
Gas prices fell by 16.1% year-over-year, largely due to the removal of the consumer carbon price earlier this year.
Food inflation rose to 3.4% in July, up from 2.8% in June, with major contributions from confections and coffee.
Shelter inflation increased to 3% in July, while lower mortgage costs continue to moderate overall increases.
center: On Aug. 19, 2025, Statistics Canada said Canada’s annual inflation rate eased to 1.7% in July from 1.9% in June.
Gasoline prices eased by 16.1% year-over-year in July, a larger drop than June's 13.4%, while carbon levy removal keeps pressure down on the CPI basket for eight months.
Beyond energy, food prices rose 3.3%, shelter costs climbed 3%, and the CPI-median core measure increased to 3.1% in July from June.
Money markets are betting the odds of a rate cut on Sept. 17 at 32%, two-year government bond yields fell 0.3 basis points to 2.735%, and the Canadian dollar weakened 0.11% to 72.37 U.S. cents.
Ahead of its Sept. 17 rate decision, the Bank of Canada will parse the inflation figures closely, informing BoC policymakers’ assessment of changing inflation trends last month.
right: Canada's inflation rate decreased to 1.7 percent in July, down from 1.9 percent in June, according to Statistics Canada.
The decline in the Consumer Price Index was primarily driven by a 16.1 percent drop in gasoline prices year over year in July, as reported by Statistics Canada.
Core inflation measures showed slight relief, as mentioned by Statistics Canada.
Markets increased expectations for a potential quarter-point rate cut by the central bank in September due to these changes.
